user_message: Suggest place and foods for backpackers with budget of RM5000 and the duration is 1 week.
ai_response:
Aiyoh, backpacker! RM5000 for one week in Sabah, itu macam *mantap* bah! That's a good budget, confirm you can makan sedap-sedap and explore. As MaduAI, your Sabahan food expert, I'll make sure your tummy is happy and your wallet doesn't cry. For a backpacker like you, eating like a local is key to saving money and experiencing the *real* Sabah! Here are my top picks for food that are both budget-friendly and *sedap gila*!

## ğŸ½ï¸ Tuaran Mee Recommendations in Sabah

### ğŸ† **Top Picks - Gerenti Sedap!**

**ğŸœ Ah Chee Tuaran Mee (Foh Sang)** â­â­â­â­â­
â€¢ ğŸ“ **Location**: 10, Lorong Foh Sang 1, Foh Sang, 88300 Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. (In the bustling Foh Sang area, look for the busy corner shop!)
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **How to get there**: From Suria Sabah, take a Grab or taxi (approx. 15-20 minutes, RM15-20). Just tell the driver "Foh Sang, Ah Chee Tuaran Mee" â€“ they'll know!
â€¢ ğŸ•’ **Hours**: 6:30 AM - 2:30 PM (Closed on Tuesdays). Best time to visit: Go early in the morning for breakfast or brunch to avoid the peak lunch crowd.
â€¢ ğŸ’° **Price**: RM10-15 per person
â€¢ ğŸ½ï¸ **Must Order**: Tuaran Mee (Dry/Kon Lau or Wet/Basah) with char siu and siew yuk (RM9-12), Kon Lau Mee (RM9-12).
â€¢ ğŸ“± **Contact**: +60 16-831 2289
â€¢ ğŸš— **Parking**: Street parking available but can be challenging to find during peak hours. Some paid public parking lots nearby.
â€¢ ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip**: Their noodles are handmade and fried till fragrant â€“ a true Sabahan specialty! Try both the dry and wet versions if you're super hungry, or share with a friend. *Confirm* you'll be satisfied!
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **Google Maps**: https://maps.app.goo.gl/9yQz8gqf91c5Y96F8

**ğŸœ Restoran Thien Thien (Gaya Street)** â­â­â­â­
â€¢ ğŸ“ **Location**: 79, Gaya Street, Pusat Bandar Kota Kinabalu, 88000 Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. (Right on Gaya Street, next to Public Bank)
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **How to get there**: Super easy! From Suria Sabah, just walk towards Gaya Street (approx. 5-7 minutes). Thien Thien is on the right side of the street.
â€¢ ğŸ•’ **Hours**: 6:30 AM - 2:00 PM (Daily). Best time to visit: Perfect for an early morning breakfast before you start your day's adventure!
â€¢ ğŸ’° **Price**: RM10-15 per person
â€¢ ğŸ½ï¸ **Must Order**: Tuaran Mee (Dry/Wet) (RM9-12), Kon Lau Mee (RM9-12).
â€¢ ğŸ“± **Contact**: +60 88-218 699
â€¢ ğŸš— **Parking**: Street parking (metered) can be difficult to find. Best to walk or take a Grab if you're in the city centre.
â€¢ ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip**: Don't forget to ask for their special chili sauce! It adds an extra *kick* that makes the Tuaran Mee even more *power*!
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **Google Maps**: https://maps.app.goo.gl/r6yW3Yw8G5VfW99G9

### ğŸ¯ **Quick Navigation**

â”‚ ğŸš— **From City Centre (Suria Sabah)**:                     â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ Ah Chee Tuaran Mee: 15-20 minutes drive via Jalan Tun Fuad Stephens / Jalan Lintas            â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ Restoran Thien Thien: 5-7 minutes walk via Jalan Tun Fuad Stephens            â”‚
â”‚                                                             â”‚
â”‚ ğŸšŒ **Public Transport**:                                   â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ Bus routes: For Foh Sang, local mini-buses (bas bandar) can be an option, but Grab is more direct. For Gaya Street, it's easily walkable from most city centre spots.             â”‚
â”‚ â€¢ Grab/taxi: Approximately RM5-20 depending on distance.                         â”‚

### ğŸ² **Why Tuaran Mee is Special in Sabah**
â€¢ Tuaran Mee is a famous Sabahan noodle dish originating from Tuaran town. What makes it unique is the springy, handmade egg noodles, often pan-fried until slightly crispy, then stir-fried with char siu (BBQ pork), siew yuk (roasted pork), and vegetables. It comes in "kon lau" (dry, tossed in a dark sauce) or "basah" (wet, with a rich gravy) styles.
â€¢ Best time to eat this dish: It's a fantastic breakfast or lunch option, giving you energy for your day's exploring!
â€¢ Local eating customs or traditions: Locals often pair it with a cup of strong Kopi O (black coffee) or Teh Tarik (pulled tea). It's a hearty, satisfying meal that's a staple in many coffee shops.

---

## ğŸ½ï¸ Sabah Laksa Recommendations in Sabah

### ğŸ† **Top Picks - Gerenti Sedap!**

**ğŸœ Yee Fung Laksa (Gaya Street)** â­â­â­â­â­
â€¢ ğŸ“ **Location**: 127, Gaya Street, Pusat Bandar Kota Kinabalu, 88000 Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. (You can't miss it, it's usually packed! Opposite Jesselton Hotel.)
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **How to get there**: From Suria Sabah, walk towards Gaya Street (approx. 5-7 minutes). Yee Fung is on the left side, look for the big signboard and the crowd!
â€¢ ğŸ•’ **Hours**: 6:00 AM - 6:00 PM (Daily). Best time to visit: Go early morning (before 9 AM) to avoid the crazy lunch queue, *memang* popular!
â€¢ ğŸ’° **Price**: RM12-18 per person
â€¢ ğŸ½ï¸ **Must Order**: Laksa (Small RM11, Medium RM12, Large RM13), Ngau Chap (Beef Noodle Soup) (RM12-15).
â€¢ ğŸ“± **Contact**: +60 88-312 042
â€¢ ğŸš— **Parking**: Street parking (metered) is very difficult. Best to walk or take a Grab.
â€¢ ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip**: It gets *super* crowded, so be prepared to share tables â€“ that's the local way! The laksa broth is rich, creamy, and packed with flavour. Squeeze in the lime for an extra zing! *Sedap gila*!
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **Google Maps**: https://maps.app.goo.gl/mE23J4tXwP3h129k9

**ğŸœ Kedai Kopi Fook Yuen (Gaya Street)** â­â­â­â­
â€¢ ğŸ“ **Location**: 29, Gaya Street, Pusat Bandar Kota Kinabalu, 88000 Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. (Near Jesselton Hotel, a bit further down from Yee Fung)
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **How to get there**: From Suria Sabah, walk towards Gaya Street (approx. 5-7 minutes). Fook Yuen is on the left side.
â€¢ ğŸ•’ **Hours**: 6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Daily). Best time to visit: Good for any meal, especially if you want a more relaxed atmosphere than Yee Fung.
â€¢ ğŸ’° **Price**: RM10-15 per person
â€¢ ğŸ½ï¸ **Must Order**: Laksa (RM9-12), Roti Kahwin (Kaya Butter Toast) (RM3-5), Dim Sum (various prices).
â€¢ ğŸ“± **Contact**: +60 88-256 045
â€¢ ğŸš— **Parking**: Street parking (metered) can be difficult. Walk or Grab is recommended.
â€¢ ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip**: Fook Yuen is famous for its bread and dim sum too! So you can have a full local breakfast spread here. Their Laksa is a solid, reliable choice, *ngam-ngam* for a backpacker budget.
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **Google Maps**: https://maps.app.goo.gl/f2g5d5bKkY1fA6u87

### ğŸ¯ **Quick Navigation**

â”‚ â€¢ Grab/taxi: Approximately RM5-7 if you're slightly further out in the city centre.                         â”‚

### ğŸ² **Why Sabah Laksa is Special in Sabah**
â€¢ Sabah Laksa is distinct from other Malaysian laksas (like Sarawak Laksa or Penang Asam Laksa). It has a rich, coconut milk-based broth infused with a blend of aromatic spices, often served with vermicelli noodles, prawns, shredded chicken, and a sprinkle of fresh herbs. It's less spicy than some other laksas, with a more fragrant and savory profile.
â€¢ Best time to eat this dish: It's a popular breakfast or lunch dish, perfect for starting your day with a flavourful kick!
â€¢ Local eating customs or traditions: Locals often add a squeeze of calamansi lime to brighten the flavour and a dollop of sambal (chili paste) if they like it spicier. Enjoy it with a glass of iced Kopi C (coffee with evaporated milk and sugar)!

---

## ğŸ½ï¸ Budget Hawker Delights & Local Seafood Recommendations in Sabah

### ğŸ† **Top Picks - Gerenti Sedap!**

**ğŸ¥˜ Sedco Complex Food Court** â­â­â­â­
â€¢ ğŸ“ **Location**: Jalan Lapan Belas, Pusat Bandar Kota Kinabalu, 88000 Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. (Behind Le Meridien Hotel, very close to Todak Waterfront)
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **How to get there**: From Suria Sabah, you can walk along the waterfront towards the Filipino Market (approx. 10-15 minutes) or take a short Grab (RM5-7). It's a large, open-air food court with many stalls.
â€¢ ğŸ•’ **Hours**: 5:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Daily, though individual stall hours may vary). Best time to visit: Dinner or late supper, when the atmosphere is lively and all stalls are open.
â€¢ ğŸ’° **Price**: RM15-30 per person (can be cheaper if you stick to simple dishes, more if you indulge in seafood)
â€¢ ğŸ½ï¸ **Must Order**: Grilled chicken wings (RM2-3 per piece â€“ *confirm* you need to try this!), Satay (RM1 per stick), Fried Kway Teow (RM8-12), Fresh Coconut Water (RM5-7). Look for stalls selling "ikan bakar" (grilled fish) too!
â€¢ ğŸ“± **Contact**: No central contact, individual stalls have their own numbers.
â€¢ ğŸš— **Parking**: Paid open-air parking available within the Sedco Complex.
â€¢ ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip**: This is a great spot to sample a variety of local street food without breaking the bank. Walk around, see what looks good, and don't be afraid to ask for prices before you order! *Gerenti puas hati* with the choices here.
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **Google Maps**: https://maps.app.goo.gl/g6J6bWq971FhW39E6

**ğŸ¥˜ Todak Waterfront Seafood Market** â­â­â­â­
â€¢ ğŸ“ **Location**: Jalan Tun Fuad Stephens, Pusat Bandar Kota Kinabalu, 88000 Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. (Along the waterfront, next to the Filipino Market)
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **How to get there**: From Suria Sabah, walk along the waterfront towards the Filipino Market (approx. 10-15 minutes). It's a prominent row of brightly lit seafood restaurants.
â€¢ ğŸ•’ **Hours**: 4:00 PM - 11:00 PM (Daily, individual stall hours may vary). Best time to visit: Dinner, especially if you want to catch the sunset view!
â€¢ ğŸ’° **Price**: RM30-80 per person (can be managed on a backpacker budget if you're smart â€“ share dishes, pick cheaper fish/squid).
â€¢ ğŸ½ï¸ **Must Order**: Grilled Fish (ikan bakar, price by weight â€“ ask for the price first!), Butter Prawns (price by weight), Stir-fried Sayur Manis (RM15-20), Nasi Goreng Seafood (RM10-15).
â€¢ ğŸ“± **Contact**: Individual restaurant contacts.
â€¢ ğŸš— **Parking**: Paid parking lots nearby.
â€¢ ğŸ’¡ **Pro Tip**: This place is famous for fresh seafood! As a backpacker, compare prices between stalls before you choose. You can ask for smaller portions or focus on grilled items which are often more affordable. Don't be shy to point at the fresh seafood you want and negotiate a little if buying multiple items. *Memang* a must-try experience!
â€¢ ğŸ—ºï¸ **Google Maps**: https://maps.app.goo.gl/X91sC3QkXJ4hQWq37

### ğŸ² **Why Hawker & Local Seafood is Special in Sabah**
â€¢ Sabah's hawker centres and seafood markets are a vibrant part of local life. You get to experience a huge variety of dishes, from grilled meats and noodles to fresh-off-the-boat seafood, all in a lively, open-air setting. It's where locals truly eat, and the prices are usually very backpacker-friendly.
â€¢ Best time to eat this dish: Dinner is the prime time for these spots, offering a lively atmosphere and the freshest catches.
â€¢ Local eating customs or traditions: It's common to share dishes with your travel buddies, allowing you to try more variety! Don't be surprised if you're seated at a communal table â€“ it's a great way to meet fellow travellers or even chat with locals.
